cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: Which of the following types of clothing can help you to be seen by other drivers?
questions.answerA: Darkly-colored clothes
questions.answerB: Clothes made from synthetic materials
questions.answerC: Reflective clothes
questions.answerD: A leather jacket
questions.explanation: Be sure to wear gear that can help you and your motorcycle to be spotted by other road users. Bright, reflective clothing can make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: When riding under normal circumstances, you should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: Most motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have only a front brake.
questions.answerB: Have only a rear brake.
questions.answerC: Have brakes in both the front and rear.
questions.answerD: Have three brakes: one in the front, one in the rear, and an emergency brake.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have two brakes, one for the front wheel and one for the rear wheel.

questions.question: If you borrow a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Don’t worry about checking the tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Expect it to handle the same as your own bike.
questions.answerC: The lender will make sure the brakes work so you don't have to.
questions.answerD: Give yourself an extra cushion of space when riding to allow more time to react.
questions.explanation: If you borrow a motorcycle, make all of the same pre-ride safety checks that you would make on your own motorcycle. You should ride cautiously when using an unfamiliar motorcycle and allow yourself extra space when stopping.

questions.question: When approaching an object or uneven surface that you cannot avoid, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the motorcycle is leaning to one side.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Swerve quickly.
questions.answerD: Rise slightly off the seat to allow your legs to absorb the shock.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid riding over an obstacle or uneven surface, you should approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can, make sure that your motorcycle is upright, and rise slightly off your seat so your knees can absorb some of the force of impact. Just before contact, roll on the throttle slightly to lighten the front end.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, it is important that all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerA: The helmet is DOT-compliant.
questions.answerB: The helmet looks nice.
questions.answerC: The helmet fits snugly.
questions.answerD: The helmet does not have any defects.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you have a helmet that will provide the best possible protection, you should choose one that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards. It should fit snugly all the way around and have no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: You’ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A DOT-approved helmet.
questions.answerB: Face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head to check for vehicles in your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Rely on your mirrors to show you all of your surroundings.
questions.answerC: Point in the direction of the lane change.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get ahead of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. You should always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes. Do not rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: Motorcyclists riding in a group should avoid pairing up because:
questions.answerA: A merging driver may not see both riders.
questions.answerB: Reflections from both helmets may make it difficult for the riders to see.
questions.answerC: Riding in pairs does not allow riders the necessary space to maneuver.
questions.answerD: It is too difficult for riders on the left side of a pairing to exit a highway.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, it is never recommended for motorcyclists to ride in pairs. Neither rider will have adequate room to maneuver to avoid hazards.

questions.question: A shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Can protect a rider's face in a crash.
questions.answerB: Is only useful in protecting riders from dirt.
questions.answerC: Does not offer as much protection as goggles.
questions.answerD: Should not be used with a helmet.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can provide protection for your entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A face shield also provides routine protection from dirt, dust, insects, rain, and pebbles.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: When riding, you should not:
questions.answerA: Use your arms to hold yourself up.
questions.answerB: Be able to reach the handle grips with your arms slightly bent.
questions.answerC: Keep your feet on the footrests.
questions.answerD: Hold your knees against the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be positioned so that you are able to easily operate all controls. Sit with your arms slightly bent and use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. Keep your feet on the footrests and keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance during turns.

questions.question: It is important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: You are tired while riding.
questions.answerB: You will be slowing where other drivers won't expect it.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle brake lights are more difficult to see than the brake lights of larger vehicles, so flashing your brake light may help other drivers to notice it. You should flash you brake light before slowing down where other drivers may not expect you to slow down, such as in the middle of a block or when approaching an alley.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed as much as possible.
questions.answerB: Lean the motorcycle to one side.
questions.answerC: Speed up, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on your seat and remove your feet from the footrests.
questions.explanation: If you are unable avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Keep your motorcycle straight up and down, if possible. Just before contact, roll off the throttle slightly to lighten the front end of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Once a motorcycle helmet has been involved in a crash, it should be:
questions.answerA: Inspected closely.
questions.answerB: Replaced.
questions.answerC: Sold to another rider.
questions.answerD: Outfitted with a new chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Replace any helmet that has been worn during a crash.

questions.question: If you are riding in traffic when a small animal enters your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Do whatever you can, including swerving into other lanes, to avoid hitting the animal.
questions.answerB: Switch lanes as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Flash your lights to try to scare the animal.
questions.explanation: Do everything you safely can to avoid hitting an animal in the road. If you are in traffic, however, you should remain in your lane. Swerving into another lane of traffic to avoid hitting an animal can cause you to collide with another driver. Hitting something small is less dangerous than hitting something big.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane often contains an oily strip. This strip:
questions.answerA: Is not safe for motorcyclists at any time.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for motorcyclists, unless it is raining.
questions.answerC: Should always be avoided since other parts of the lane do not have the oily strip.
questions.answerD: Adds to traction for most motorcycle tires.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: On which of the following surfaces does a motorcycle have the best traction?
questions.answerA: Dry pavement
questions.answerB: Gravel
questions.answerC: Snow
questions.answerD: Leaves
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Provides less than half of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerB: Provides about 70 percent of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Should be the only brake you use.
questions.explanation: The front brake is much more powerful than the rear one and provides at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: Just behind the leader.
questions.answerB: In front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders behind them to keep an eye on them.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Do not have blind spots because of their small size.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots, but they are so small they should not cause concern.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that should be routinely checked.
questions.answerD: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes. Head checks should be a regular part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Always scan the road ahead and anticipate potential risks.
questions.answerB: Focus on the controls, including the speedometer, rather than the road.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with hazards, because hazards are minimal on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Always look ahead, but try not to look for hazards.
questions.explanation: When riding, always look well ahead of your vehicle to help you anticipate potential hazards. Doing this will help you react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Not use any brakes, but downshift.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed and avoid making sudden moves. Use both brakes if you must slow down or stop.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, a jacket should be worn:
questions.answerA: No matter the weather conditions.
questions.answerB: Only on cool days.
questions.answerC: Only on warm days.
questions.answerD: Only if the ride will be longer than half an hour.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket when riding, even in warm weather when you may not think you need a jacket. It can help protect you against the sun and dehydration in hot weather.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders should choose footwear with soles that:
questions.answerA: Are made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.
questions.answerB: Allow their feet to breathe.
questions.answerC: Have tall heels.
questions.answerD: Are made of soft, flimsy material.
questions.explanation: Choose riding boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Choose footwear with soles made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle's blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay where you are to avoid surprising the driver.
questions.answerB: Wave at the other driver to get their attention.
questions.answerC: Slow down until you are out of the blind spot.
questions.answerD: Pull over to the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you find yourself riding in a vehicle's blind spot, you should either speed up quickly or slow down and drop back to vacate the spot.

questions.question: Of the following, the colors that best allow riders to be seen are:
questions.answerA: Orange and red.
questions.answerB: Green and blue.
questions.answerC: Purple and gold.
questions.answerD: Black and white.
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to others, wearing clothing that is bright orange, red, yellow, or green is best.

questions.question: If you must swerve, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn your handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is discouraged because:
questions.answerA: You may have a difficult time getting to a highway exit.
questions.answerB: You may be in the other vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may block the driver's view.
questions.answerD: It prevents other drivers from passing both of you.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. The driver may enter your lane without warning if they can't see you. The vehicle will also block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: Waiting for one hour to ride after having one drink:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that you cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Guarantees that your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Should be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.answerD: May not entirely remove the effects of alcohol from your body.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate a motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always pick one part of the lane to occupy and never leave that part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Vary your lane position as conditions warrant.
questions.answerC: Only ride in the center of the lane so other vehicles can see you more easily.
questions.answerD: Ride in a zigzag pattern so other drivers notice you.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best, nor one that should always be avoided. Change your lane position as necessary based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: If your front tire goes flat while you are riding:
questions.answerA: The steering will feel heavy.
questions.answerB: The steering will feel loose.
questions.answerC: There will be no change in the steering.
questions.answerD: The ride will feel too smooth.
questions.explanation: If the front tire of a motorcycle fails, it will cause the steering to feel heavy. If your steering feels heavy, immediately exit the road and inspect your tires.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the best part of the lane for a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Often contains oil and grease, but is usually safe for riding.
questions.answerC: Often contains oil and grease, and is never safe for riding.
questions.answerD: Is the smoothest part of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this area still generally offers enough traction for motorcyclists to safely ride. You should still avoid riding on big buildups of oil and grease, often found at busy intersections or near toll booths.

questions.question: Maintain an adequate following distance behind other vehicles:
questions.answerA: To allow you time and space to identify and react to hazards.
questions.answerB: So you can tailgate.
questions.answerC: To allow for traffic counters to accurately count you as a vehicle.
questions.answerD: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate following distance ensures that you will have enough space to stop or swerve out of the way if the vehicle ahead of you stops suddenly. A space cushion also provides you with a better view of any hazards on the road surface, such as potholes.

questions.question: A wobble, or shaking of the front wheel and handlebars, may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Incorrect tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Brakes that are not working properly.
questions.answerC: A balanced load.
questions.answerD: Excessive wind.
questions.explanation: Most wobbles are caused by improper loading of the motorcycle, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle could lurch and the rear tire could skid.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle could accelerate too quickly.
questions.answerC: Front tire will likely skid.
questions.answerD: Engine will make a loud noise.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the motorcycle will lurch and the rear wheel may skid.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Twice a month.
questions.explanation: Perform an inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This takes only a few minutes and helps prevent dangerous situations before entering traffic.

questions.question: When packing a load on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The heavier items should go toward the front.
questions.answerB: The heavier items should go toward the rear.
questions.answerC: Mounting loads behind the rear axle is recommended.
questions.answerD: Lighter items should be stored in front of you.
questions.explanation: Loads should be positioned forward with heavier items toward the front of the load. Loads should be over or in front of the rear axle. Lighter items should be packed behind you.

questions.question: The effects of marijuana consumption can last for:
questions.answerA: No more than 15 minutes.
questions.answerB: About an hour.
questions.answerC: About two hours.
questions.answerD: More than six hours.
questions.explanation: When marijuana is smoked, it can begin to affect the smoker within minutes and effects can last for between two and four hours. When marijuana is eaten, it may take over an hour to begin to affect the consumer, but the effects of the marijuana may last for more than six hours.

questions.question: When riding in traffic, it is important to remember that motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots that are too small to cause any problems.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that require head checks.
questions.answerD: Have only one blind spot.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, motorcycles have blind spots. Always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerA: Be free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: Riding with a passenger:
questions.answerA: Usually results in no difference in handling a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for beginning riders.
questions.answerC: Can affect the handling of a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Is encouraged to get operators used to different riding situations.
questions.explanation: A passenger puts extra weight on a motorcycle, which causes the motorcycle to handle differently. Only experienced riders should carry passengers.

questions.question: When riding in a group, you should not:
questions.answerA: Take frequent breaks.
questions.answerB: Tailgate other riders within the group.
questions.answerC: Place inexperienced riders just behind the leaders.
questions.answerD: Switch riding formations frequently.
questions.explanation: Groups of riders should take regular breaks to reduce fatigue. Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leader so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind. It is generally best to ride in a staggered formation to most easily maintain adequate space cushions among riders.

questions.question: Which of the following will protect your eyes from the wind?
questions.answerA: Goggles
questions.answerB: Windshield
questions.answerC: Sunglasses
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields can protect a rider's eyes from the wind. Windshields, eyeglasses, and sunglasses generally do not shield a rider's eyes adequately enough.

questions.question: Braking in a turn is:
questions.answerA: Easier than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: More difficult than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Done safely by using the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Done safely by using the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Braking in a turn is not as easy as braking on a straightaway. It is possible to use both brakes to brake in a turn, but the operator must know the proper technique and exercise great care.

questions.question: Common drugs, such as cold tablets:
questions.answerA: Can affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Usually won’t affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Pose no risk to a rider's operating abilities.
questions.answerD: Are always acceptable to take before riding because they are sold over-the-counter.
questions.explanation: Almost all drugs, including over-the-counter medications, have the potential to impact the abilities you need to ride safely. Make sure you understand the side effects of any drug before combining it with riding.

questions.question: Unlike most food and drinks, alcohol does not need to be digested. This means that:
questions.answerA: Within minutes of being consumed, the alcohol reaches the brain and begins to affect the drinker.
questions.answerB: The alcohol never gets removed from the body.
questions.answerC: It takes a long time to feel the effects of alcohol.
questions.answerD: Once it is in your system, your body gets rid of the alcohol quickly.
questions.explanation: Because it does not have to be digested, alcohol enters a person's bloodstream quickly and reaches the brain within minutes. It gets eliminated from the body at a relatively slow rate: about one drink per hour.

questions.question: If a rider in a group wants to ride faster than the others, what should the group do?
questions.answerA: Let the rider go ahead and meet up at a designated spot later.
questions.answerB: Speed up to accommodate the one rider.
questions.answerC: Split up and have every rider travel as fast or as slow as they want.
questions.answerD: Let the rider that wants to go faster lead the group.
questions.explanation: If one member of a group wants to ride faster than the others, it is best to let them go ahead of the group and meet at a designated spot later.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerA: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.answerB: Cars leaving their parking spaces.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Noise.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Never be worn.
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight. Increasing your visibility by wearing bright colors and reflective materials is a good idea at all times.

questions.question: A three-wheeled motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Handles curves about the same as a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Handles curves differently than a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Should not be operated in curves.
questions.answerD: Should use the shoulder when taking a curve.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle.

questions.question: When entering a curve, a group should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerB: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in pairs.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best, a group should switch into a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When it is raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Wet pavement is especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Deposits of oil left by cars will not yet have washed off the roadway. If it is raining, it is safest to ride in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track will often be your best choice, although this may vary.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Passing another vehicle.
questions.answerB: You will be slowing down suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals do not work.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle's single brake light is not as noticeable as the two larger brake lights of a car or truck. It can be a good idea to flash your brake light to help others notice it, especially when you need to slow down more quickly than surrounding drivers may expect.

questions.question: When making normal stops, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: Make it a habit to always use both brakes when slowing or stopping, even for normal, non-emergency stops.

questions.question: If you are riding in the right side of your lane while following a car:
questions.answerA: You are likely riding in the best position to be seen.
questions.answerB: You may not be seen unless the driver uses their side mirror.
questions.answerC: The driver will most likely assume you are there.
questions.answerD: You are discouraging other drivers from sharing your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: How do headache, cold, and hay fever medications usually affect your body?
questions.answerA: They make you drowsy.
questions.answerB: They make you more alert.
questions.answerC: They make you hungry.
questions.answerD: They make you unable to concentrate.
questions.explanation: Most drugs taken to ease headaches, colds, hay fever, allergies, or nerves can make the consumer drowsy and may impair their ability to ride safely. When taking a medication, it is important for a rider to know how the drug affects their body before riding.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars, a motorcycle operator should be prepared for:
questions.answerA: Open parking spaces.
questions.answerB: A motorist to unexpectedly pull out of a parking space and into traffic.
questions.answerC: Parking meters.
questions.answerD: Other motorists to see the motorcycle and stay out of its way.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, a motorcyclist should be prepared for a parked car to suddenly pull out of a parking space and into traffic. It is often safest for a motorcyclist to ride in the left portion of their lane when passing a row of parked cars on their right to create the most possible space between their motorcycle and any potential hazards.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerA: Insects.
questions.answerB: Headlight glare.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Indicates that the driver sees you.
questions.answerB: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerC: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: May make the driver mad.
questions.explanation: Never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver will properly yield to you. It is common for drivers to look directly at motorcyclists and still fail to notice them.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding near stopped or slow-moving cars, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and wait until traffic begins to move.
questions.answerB: Ride on the shoulder to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Weave between the cars to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Not weave between the cars.
questions.explanation: Riding between slowed or parked cars can leave you vulnerable to unexpected hazards, such as opening car doors or cars suddenly pulling into traffic. If a hazard arises, you will not have room to safely maneuver. Never travel on the shoulder of a road because other drivers will never expect you to be there.

questions.question: The shortest and safest stops are accomplished:
questions.answerA: By using only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: By using only the front brake.
questions.answerC: By allowing the front tire to lock up.
questions.answerD: By using both the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: The shortest and safest stops are achieved by using both the front and rear brakes in a smooth and progressive manner, without skidding either tire.

questions.question: When you are riding on a bridge grating, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride on the far right side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride on the far left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Slowly zigzag across the grating.
questions.answerD: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.explanation: Crossing rain grooves or bridge gratings may cause your motorcycle to move in a weaving motion. This is usually not dangerous, so simply relax and proceed across the surface at a steady speed. Trying to ride at an angle to compensate for the weave is dangerous because it forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerB: Ride faster.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handle grip in the direction you plan to swerve.
questions.answerD: Press the handle grip in the direction opposite of where you plan to swerve.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: When traveling on a motorcycle with a sidecar, the passenger should ride:
questions.answerA: On the motorcycle seat.
questions.answerB: In the sidecar.
questions.answerC: Either on the motorcycle or in the sidecar.
questions.answerD: Neither on the motorcycle or in the sidecar.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle has a sidecar, it is best for your passenger to ride in the sidecar. They should keep their hands inside the sidecar at all times.

questions.question: Your motorcycle’s brake light is:
questions.answerA: More noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerB: Less noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerC: Less important than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerD: More easily seen than a car’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: The brake light of a motorcycle is usually not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car. Flashing your brake light before slowing or stopping can help other drivers notice that you are about to brake.

questions.question: In a slow, tight turn, the rider should:
questions.answerA: Counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping their body upright.
questions.answerB: Lean at the same angle as the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Lean in the opposite direction of the motorcycle and the turn.
questions.answerD: Counterbalance their leaning body by keeping the motorcycle upright.
questions.explanation: When taking normal turns, lean at the same angle as your motorcycle. However, in slow, tight turns, you should counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping your body upright.

questions.question: How can you regain control if your rear tire locks up?
questions.answerA: Release the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Continue using the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Swerve the bike in the direction with the fewest hazards.
questions.answerD: With the brake engaged, try to accelerate.
questions.explanation: To regain control of a locked rear wheel, the brake must be released. However, if you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped.

questions.question: It is a good idea to wear reflective clothing:
questions.answerA: At night.
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: At dusk.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wearing reflective and brightly-colored clothing is always a good idea when riding a motorcycle. Crashes occur in broad daylight and at night, so it is best to wear highly visible clothing at any time of day.

questions.question: When traveling through a curve, the best lane position:
questions.answerA: Is the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Is the far right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Changes based on the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is best for all curves. The best position may even change within a single curve. All curves are different, and the road geometry, traffic, road conditions may change as you move through a curve.

questions.question: If you lock the rear tire on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Release and re-apply the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Keep it locked until you completely stop.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and use both brakes to stop.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. You should still be able to steer your motorcycle with a locked rear wheel.

questions.question: When riding a three-wheeled motorcycle through a curve, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay on the outside of the lane.
questions.answerC: Change your path as needed.
questions.answerD: Use the shoulder.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle. The best path for a three-wheeler to take through a curve may not actually follow the curve. For example, you may need to move from the outside of the curve to the inside of the curve before straightening out your path.

questions.question: Do not change gears on railroad tracks because:
questions.answerA: Your motorcycle may stall.
questions.answerB: You might go too fast.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may not be expecting you to change gears.
questions.answerD: The uneven surface may make it more difficult to switch gears.
questions.explanation: It is best not to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks. There is a chance your motorcycle might stall while you are on the tracks.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerA: Safe, if used properly.
questions.answerB: Safe, even if used improperly.
questions.answerC: Only to be used if the rear brake fails.
questions.answerD: Not to be used regularly.
questions.explanation: The front brake is safe to use as long as it is used properly. The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing at least three-fourths of the total stopping power.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the best protection for motorcycle riders?
questions.answerA: Leather
questions.answerB: Denim
questions.answerC: Wool
questions.answerD: Polyester
questions.explanation: Jackets and pants made of leather offer the greatest degree of protection to those riding motorcycles.

questions.question: The best lane position:
questions.answerA: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Varies based on road, weather, and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. You should vary your lane position in response to changes in riding conditions.

questions.question: When riding in a group while passing another vehicle, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Allow one rider to fully pass the other vehicle before another rider begins to pass.
questions.answerB: Allow several members of the group to pass the other vehicle at once.
questions.answerC: Have the last rider in the group wave to the driver being passed to signal that no other motorcycles are approaching.
questions.answerD: Pass in a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: Riders in a group should overtake another vehicle one at a time. Each rider should complete their pass and resume their position in the group formation before the next rider begins to pass.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster than usual.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time could result in all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Fatigue.
questions.answerB: Hypothermia.
questions.answerC: Severe chills.
questions.answerD: Hot flashes.
questions.explanation: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time can cause severe chill, fatigue, and even hypothermia. Be sure to wear proper clothing to protect you from the elements.

questions.question: When securing a load, you should place the load:
questions.answerA: As high as possible.
questions.answerB: As low as possible.
questions.answerC: On a sissy bar.
questions.answerD: Only on one side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Secured loads should be low. Putting them too high up, such as on a sissy bar, can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance. Loads should be as evenly distributed as possible on each side of the motorcycle to avoid pulling the bike to one side.

questions.question: When looking through a turn to see where you are going, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn just your head.
questions.answerB: Turn your head and shoulders.
questions.answerC: Turn just your shoulders.
questions.answerD: Turn your entire body.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When planning a long group ride, which of the following ideas should not be implemented?
questions.answerA: The lengths of travel segments should be based on the least experienced rider.
questions.answerB: Breaks should be minimized so the riders can get to their destination as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leaders.
questions.answerD: The group should maintain a staggered riding formation.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, the length of a route and the lengths of segments of travel should be based on the skill level of the least experienced rider. Groups of riders should take regular breaks to reduce fatigue. Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leader so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind. It is generally best to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: A motorcycle “fits” you if:
questions.answerA: You are able to touch your feet to the ground while seated.
questions.answerB: You are able to reach the controls by stretching.
questions.answerC: The handlebars go over your head.
questions.answerD: Your feet are unable to rest on the foot pegs.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you properly if your feet can reach the ground while you are seated on the motorcycle. It should be easy for you to reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving an accident is:
questions.answerA: Wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Read books on motorcycle safety.
questions.answerC: Ask others about how to ride more safely.
questions.answerD: Watch training videos.
questions.explanation: The single most important measure you can take to reduce your risk of injury or death in the event of an accident is to wear a helmet.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake suddenly.
questions.answerB: Steer in a weaving pattern.
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerA: As low as possible
questions.answerB: As high as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: A face shield should:
questions.answerA: Allow a clear view to both sides.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from passing through it.
questions.answerC: Be tight enough to prevent glasses from fitting underneath it.
questions.answerD: Should not fasten too tightly.
questions.explanation: To be effective, a face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: To prevent getting fatigued on a long ride, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Dress warmly.
questions.answerB: Limit the distance traveled in a day.
questions.answerC: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerD: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Ignore them.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by causing them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerB: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When deciding on a lane position, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Always ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Be flexible and base your decision off of numerous factors.
questions.explanation: In general, there is no single best lane position. No portion of the lane need be avoided at all times. Position yourself in the portion of the lane where you are most likely to be seen and you can maintain a cushion of space around you.

questions.question: As weight transfers to the front of your bike while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Gradually increase pressure to the front brake.
questions.answerB: Use more rear brake pressure.
questions.answerC: Not worry. The weight transfer will not have an effect on your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Try to lock the front tire.
questions.explanation: While you are braking, gradually increase the amount of pressure applied to the front brake lever as the weight of the bike is transferred forward to the front tire.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake when slowing or stopping.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes when slowing or stopping.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when slowing or stopping, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be alert to oily areas, dirt, gravel, shaded areas, and bridges, as these surfaces are more likely to be slippery than others.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: When is it important for a rider to use their mirrors?
questions.answerA: When slowing down or stopping suddenly
questions.answerB: When stopped at an intersection
questions.answerC: When changing lanes
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: It is particularly important for a rider to check their mirrors when slowing down or stopping, when stopped at an intersection, when changing lanes, and when turning.

questions.question: A used helmet with visible cracks:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable.
questions.answerB: Will likely still provide adequate protection.
questions.answerC: May be compromised and should not be used.
questions.answerD: Is okay as long as the helmet still fits snugly.
questions.explanation: Helmets can provide the best protection when they meet DOT standards and have no signs of damage. A helmet that has been damaged should be replaced.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: To best control a motorcycle, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Sit with their arms fully extended.
questions.answerB: Use their arms to hold their body up.
questions.answerC: Keep their knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Keep their feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so that you can use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you hold the handgrips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: What should you do to maintain proper control of your motorcycle while turning?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed before entering the turn.
questions.answerB: Keep the motorcycle from leaning.
questions.answerC: Look through the turn to anticipate the best course of action.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before entering the turn.
questions.explanation: To maintain directional control through a turn, you should look through the turn by turning only your head. Slow down before turning and lean your motorcycle in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: When choosing a helmet, you will get the most protection by using a helmet that:
questions.answerA: Fits loosely.
questions.answerB: Meets U.S. DOT standards.
questions.answerC: Has survived a previous crash.
questions.answerD: Provides hearing protection.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you are getting as much protection as possible, choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. Helmets should fit snugly all the way around.

questions.question: If preparing to carry a passenger, you will not need to adjust the:
questions.answerA: Tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Suspension.
questions.answerC: Headlight.
questions.answerD: Brake light.
questions.explanation: Due to the added weight of a passenger on a motorcycle, be sure to adjust the tire pressure, adjust the suspension settings, and reposition the headlight, if necessary.

questions.question: A group of riders should merge onto a highway in:
questions.answerA: A single-file formation.
questions.answerB: A staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Pairs.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best under normal riding conditions, a group of riders should switch to a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the motorcycle is as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Assume other drivers can’t see you.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with taking steps to ensure that other drivers see you.
questions.answerD: Ride offensively.
questions.explanation: Because motorcycles are small in stature and have fewer and smaller lights than other vehicles, they can be difficult to see. For your safety, it is best to ride defensively and assume that others on the road do not see you.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, make sure it is all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Designed to meet U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: Snug.
questions.answerC: Defect-free.
questions.answerD: Attractive.
questions.explanation: You should select a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation and state standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Means that the other driver knows you are there.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact with another driver as a guarantee that they will properly yield the right-of-way to you.

questions.question: You should use a larger cushion of space:
questions.answerA: When roads are slippery.
questions.answerB: When it is sunny outside.
questions.answerC: When it is colder than usual.
questions.answerD: When you are following other motorcycles.
questions.explanation: A two-second following distance is generally appropriate. Allow a larger cushion of space when riding under conditions that will increase your stopping distance, such as when the road surface is icy or wet.

questions.question: The faster you drink:
questions.answerA: The more the alcohol will accumulate in your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerC: The more minimal the effects of the alcohol will be.
questions.answerD: The more likely you will be able to evade being pulled over.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the more alcohol will accumulate in your body. It is never safe to operate a motor vehicle after drinking alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: Approved helmets:
questions.answerA: Can limit the view of the motorcycle operator.
questions.answerB: Allow the motorcycle operator to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerC: Are dangerous to wear.
questions.answerD: Do not have to be worn if the motorcycle operator thinks their view would be limited.
questions.explanation: While some people worry that wearing a helmet may dangerously limit their field of vision, this is not the case. Any approved helmet will let the operator see as far to the sides as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: Which formation is best for keeping the riders in a group close together?
questions.answerA: Pyramid
questions.answerB: Staggered
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: How often should engine oil and transmission fluid levels be checked?
questions.answerA: Before every ride
questions.answerB: Once a week
questions.answerC: Once a month
questions.answerD: Once a year
questions.explanation: You should check your motorcycle's engine oil and transmission fluid levels before every ride.

questions.question: If it starts to rain, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the portion of the lane that has tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerC: In the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: Roads can be particularly slippery when it starts to rain. It is safest to ride in the tire tracks left by cars.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Just behind the lead rider.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Anywhere within the group.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride near the front of a group, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: When braking:
questions.answerA: Use only one brake if it is a non-emergency situation.
questions.answerB: Only use both brakes if you are riding on wet pavement.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes regardless of the circumstances.
questions.answerD: Use only the front brake.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerC: Popping a tire.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane usually contains an oily strip. This part of the lane is:
questions.answerA: Never safe for motorcyclists.
questions.answerB: Usually safe, unless the road is wet.
questions.answerC: Usually safe, unless it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Always safe, no matter the weather conditions.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: When choosing a lane position, you should consider:
questions.answerA: Whether or not other drivers will see you.
questions.answerB: How many cars are on the road ahead.
questions.answerC: Which portion of the lane will result in a shorter trip.
questions.answerD: If you can pass more vehicles in a certain position than in another.
questions.explanation: While a properly chosen lane position can offer several advantages, you should be certain that your lane position will allow you to be seen by others and have an adequate space cushion.

questions.question: Studies show that most crash-involved riders:
questions.answerA: Under-brake the front tire and over-break the rear tire.
questions.answerB: Over-break the front tire and under-brake the rear tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Most riders involved in crashes under-brake the front tire and over-brake the rear.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerB: Can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: Before mounting a motorcycle, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in the tires.
questions.answerB: Fluid levels.
questions.answerC: The turn signals.
questions.answerD: Damage to the paint.
questions.explanation: Before getting on a motorcycle, you should check the tread and air pressure of the tires, the oil and fluid levels, the lights, and the signals.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerA: Two times
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up before contact.
questions.answerB: Slow down before contact.
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Get as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerD: Not signal your intentions, as that may distract the driver you are passing.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. Signal your intentions and check for traffic. Pass when it is safe to do so, then signal and return to your original lane when traffic allows.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerA: Wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Lean when the operator leans.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: When exiting a highway while riding in a group, which riding formation should be used?
questions.answerA: Staggered
questions.answerB: Single-file
questions.answerC: Paired up
questions.answerD: Riding three across a lane
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best for group riding, a group should switch into a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Move onto the shoulder to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Speed up and put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerC: Ignore them.
questions.answerD: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: Usually, the best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to follow you at a faster speed.

questions.question: When braking where traction is reduced, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes more quickly than usual.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes more gently than usual.
questions.answerC: Not use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Not use the front brake.
questions.explanation: When slowing or stopping on a surface with reduced traction, you should use caution and apply the brakes more gently than usual.

questions.question: Where is the electric starter button usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left handgrip
questions.answerB: Near the right handgrip
questions.answerC: By the left footrest
questions.answerD: By the right footrest
questions.explanation: The electric starter button is generally located near the right handgrip.

questions.question: Where is the engine cut-off switch usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left handgrip
questions.answerB: Near the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The engine cut-off switch is generally located near the right handgrip.

questions.question: Which of the following will help you ride safely on slippery surfaces?
questions.answerA: Using only the front brake
questions.answerB: Using both brakes
questions.answerC: Using the center lane
questions.answerD: Maintaining or increasing your speed
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, reduce your speed, brake using both brakes, and avoid sudden moves. Avoid the center of the lane and instead follow tire tracks left by cars. Always keep an eye out for hazards that may make a road surface especially slippery, such as oil spots and loose gravel.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerA: Air pressure
questions.answerB: General wear
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerD: Use your high beam light, if possible.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. Use your high beam headlight, except when following or meeting another vehicle.

questions.question: You should completely check your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a year.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle requires more frequent attention than a car. Make a complete check of your motorcycle before every ride.
